label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Zombie Queues
I'm using the messaging service via the REST interface

I seem to have several; queues which are empty but which cannot be deleted.

Here is an example:

http://webservices.amazon.com/onca/xml?Service=AWSSimpleQueueService&SubscriptionId=[removed]&Operation=Read&QueueId=&ltAccess Key Removed>&ReadCount=25

produces
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<ReadResponse xmlns="http://webservices.amazon.com/AWSSimpleQueueService/2004-10-14">
    <OperationRequest>
        <HTTPHeaders>
            <Header Name="UserAgent" Value="Java/1.4.2"/>
        </HTTPHeaders>
        <RequestId>&ltAccess Key Removed></RequestId>
        <Arguments>
            <Argument Name="Service" Value="AWSSimpleQueueService"/>
            <Argument Name="SubscriptionId" Value="[removed]"/>
            <Argument Name="QueueId" Value="&ltAccess Key Removed>"/>
            <Argument Name="Operation" Value="Read"/>
            <Argument Name="ReadCount" Value="25"/>
        </Arguments>
    </OperationRequest>
    <ReadResult>
        <Request>
            <IsValid>True</IsValid>
            <ReadRequest>
                <QueueId>&ltAccess Key Removed></QueueId>
                <ReadCount>25</ReadCount>
            </ReadRequest>
        </Request>
        <SimpleQueueServiceError>
            <ErrorCode>AWS.SimpleQueueService.NoData</ErrorCode>
            <ReasonText>Success, but no data was found in the queue.</ReasonText>
        </SimpleQueueServiceError>
    </ReadResult>
</ReadResponse>

so there are no messages in the queue

http://webservices.amazon.com/onca/xml?Service=AWSSimpleQueueService&SubscriptionId=[removed]&Operation=DeleteQueue&QueueId=&ltAccess Key Removed>

produces

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<DeleteQueueResponse xmlns="http://webservices.amazon.com/AWSSimpleQueueService/2004-10-14">
    <OperationRequest>
        <HTTPHeaders>
            <Header Name="UserAgent" Value="Java/1.4.2"/>
        </HTTPHeaders>
        <RequestId>&ltAccess Key Removed></RequestId>
        <Arguments>
            <Argument Name="Service" Value="AWSSimpleQueueService"/>
            <Argument Name="SubscriptionId" Value="[removed]"/>
            <Argument Name="QueueId" Value="&ltAccess Key Removed>"/>
            <Argument Name="Operation" Value="DeleteQueue"/>
        </Arguments>
    </OperationRequest>
    <DeleteQueueResult>
        <Request>
            <IsValid>True</IsValid>
            <DeleteQueueRequest>
                <QueueId>&ltAccess Key Removed></QueueId>
            </DeleteQueueRequest>
        </Request>
        <SimpleQueueServiceError>
            <ErrorCode>AWS.SimpleQueueService.NonEmptyQueue</ErrorCode>
            <ReasonText>Queue can't be deleted because it still has entries that need to be dequeued first.</ReasonText>
        </SimpleQueueServiceError>
    </DeleteQueueResult>
</DeleteQueueResponse>

This is not a one off, I have four queues which exhibit this behaviour.

I have left the queues for several hours before trying to delete them and the problem persists.

John wilson

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Deleteing a queue fails
If I empty a queue immediately  after dequeing all the messages in it I get a failure saying that the queue is not empty. If I sleep for a bit and delete the queue then it works.

I'm guessing that I need to wait for at least ReadLockTimeoutSeconds after dequing the last message before I can delete it. Is that so or is there another magic number?

I can't find any reference to this in the documentation. Would it be possible to add something to cover this issue to the documentation?

If I do need to wait ReadLockTimeoutSeconds I would really like an API to retrieve this for a single queue. I know that ListMyQueues will give me this for all queues but I may have thousands of queues so that call would be expensive to make.

       John Wilson

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Deleteing a queue fails
The "magic number" you need to wait between dequeuing the last entry and deleting the queue is 60 seconds. It's unrelated to the read-lock timeout, but rather it represents the time it takes for the change to propagate through our system.

You are right -- this quirk should definitely be documented.

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Deleteing a queue fails
Thanks John, the code seems to be performing reliably with a 60 second sleep 

        John Wilson

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Control characters in messages
The REST interface to the Amazon Simple Queue Service lets you include arbitrary control characters in the message when using the enqueue operation. This causes a couple of problems

1/ if you include the NULL character (value 0) then the message is truncated at that point (there's C code behind this interface isn't there?)

2/ Other control characters are accepted OK. However when the message is read the response is not well formed XML

Point 2 is the killer. An XML document may not contain control characters other than CR, NL and HT. You can't include control characters by using &x01 or by any other trick. That just can't be in the document at all.

The result of this is that the system allows you to post messages which cannot be retrieved by software which uses XML compliant components (i.e. a normal XML parser). This is a really big problem which you have to fix ASAP.

The REST layer needs to check for control characters and reject messages containing them.

Note this is (or should be) a REST only problem. The SOAP interface is XML so your SOAP implementation will (or should) reject a SOAP document which contains illegal control characters as the XML will be non well formed.

John Wilson

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Control characters in messages
There is another, related, problem....

As far as I can see the REST layer is assuming that the URL is UTF-8 encoded Unicode (this is fine and corresponds to the W3C and IETF views on encoding URIs as I understand them)

Unfortunately it does not check that the UTF-8 encoding is correct. If you supply a message which has bad UTF-8 encoding it is placed in the queue and this causes the XML produced as a result of the read operation to be corrupt (i.e. it contains the bad UTF-8 encoding)

John Wilson

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Control characters in messages
John,
I just wanted to post a reply to let you know that we've noted these issues and are researching implications and potential resolution.
Thanks for posting.  And thank you in general for your great feedback!
-DaveQueue PM

description:
ListMyQueues when there are no queues
Hi Duane,

Yes the error was a response to a mangled URL. However I would still expect the response to be in some namespace or other. You seem to be using namespaces as a versioning device for the API. I would expect you to want to version these error responses in exactly the same way as the non error responses.

If I get one of these errors I want to know if it's in a format I'm familiar with (i.e. I know about the namespace URI) or if it's a newer format in which case I need to log the fact that my software needs updating. At the moment, because there is no namespace, I can't tell if I should be able to understand the response or not. In addition these responses are undocumented as your schema only covers the namespace http://webservices.amazon.com/AWSSimpleQueueService/2004-10-14.

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
AWIS SOAP Fix for missing parameters Current WDSL contains bugs, and we cannot generate valid SOAP request. Therefore, we only receive missing required argument error. But, updated WDSL is not available yet. We can wait official release of updated WSDL. But, I couldn't wait and modified WSDL manufally. I checked in Apache Axis and .NET(C#) and both worked correctly. I'm not good at English and cannot describe properly. So I'll show the full code related to this issue. I'll take UrlInfo operation as a example, but this issue applies to all the operations. [UrlInfo operation] A SOAP request generated from current WSDL is looks like this: ${SubscriptionId} TrafficData www.w3c.org But response from this request is rejected like this: AWS.MissingParameters Your request is missing required parameters. Required parameters include Url. A valid request for AWIS is: ${SubscriptionId} TrafficData www.w3c.org To generate this SOAP request, current WSDL should be fixed like this: Possible FIX (1): Possible FIX (2): If you are ".Net" user, you may not required to modify WSDL. I modified reference file like this: [System.Xml.Serialization.XmlElementAttribute("UrlInfoRequest")] FIX: [System.Xml.Serialization.XmlElementAttribute("Request")] FYI: More fix in the WSDL, see this post. http://forums.prospero.com/n/mb/message.asp?webtag=am-assocdevxml&msg=6573.1&ctx=0 takeuma
Edited 11/7/2004 12:10 am ET by takeuma

description:
Spiegel Apparel Chaos and Losing Images   Spiegel Apparel Chaos and Losing Images in ECS Losing the ECS Medium Image after it existed. I don't blame Amazon or the AWS Team .... And this has nothing to do with the Seasons, The Fall, The Winter, the cold changing garments, etc ... This is sheer madness and chaos !! Perhaps this is the indiscipline of a Brand that has always been chaotic in Apparel. The champion of Anarchy and changing everything everyday. The Spiegel Apparel brand loses images in ECS like this one : http://xml.amazon.com/onca/xml?Service=AWSECommerceService&Operation=ItemLookup&Style=http%3A//www.gamefant.com/vico.xslt&ContentType=text/html&SubscriptionId=<Access Key Removed>&ItemId=B000623G1W&IdType=ASIN&MerchantId=All&ResponseGroup=Large,VariationSummary&Version=2004-10-04 Previously the Garment Image was shown ( a Sweater ) ... Now it is lost in ECS for XSLT. Spiegel has always been the champion of indiscipline changing Asin number with extraordinary frequency and killing big collections for a week or fifteen days.... Later they appear with changed ASIN number and later all the resurrected collection is killed once again for days or weeks. I am not talking about all Spiegel Products but a good percentage. While other champions of indiscipline have been corrected and are now good kids, Spiegel seems every day worse in behaviour. The AWS Team has done a wonderful job with ECS ... This is magic and its performance and reliability is extraordinary. But the employees of a brand can do a lot to discredit ECS by erasing the images or killing collections without any explanation. Later the resurrection of the dead is killed once again. This is an absurd game of "Out of Stock" . Intermittent and Crazy !! ( Not continuous or stable ) I don't see how Amazon is benefited with this erratic behaviour. Vicente  
Edited 11/5/2004 8:55 am ET by Vicente Duque

description:
Alexa 3 month change ?
Is there somewhere in a URLInfo result (or in one of the other results) that I can get the three month change in rank for a url?  Cause that would be great.  Ive done some searching and can not find it anywhere.

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Alexa 3 month change ? Yes, you can. On your UrlInfo request, use the TrafficData response group. In there you will find something like this:
- <UsageStatistics>
- <UsageStatistic>
- <TimeRange>
  <Months>3Months>
  TimeRange>
- <Rank>
  <Value>4,419Value>
  <Delta>+151Delta>
The delta is the number you are looking for. Note, the "+" indicates that the rank is a higher number... In other words, in this case, the rank went from 4268 to 4419, indicating the site is losing its position, not winning.
 
We are looking for example apps. If you build something that might be interesting, let me know. We'd love to show it off.

Apparel XSLT has collapsed - KAPUT   Wednesday, October 26, Everything was perfect in Apparel XSLT 4.0 in the early morning 7 to 8 AM Eastern Standard Time. At 8 AM everything collapsed ( someone arrived early at his office and did something !! )
   
Apparel XSLT was 80% dead with many errors. XSLT 3.0 collapsed to 30% errors after being absolutely and totally perfect during the last three months.
    Two hours later after the collapse : Things have beeen returning to normal. XSLT 3.0 has returned to perfection with 0% errors as it always was during the last three months of Happiness and XSLT 3.0 Bliss. Apparel XSLT 4.0 has been improving with less and less errors But Apparel ECS seems very slow today Wednesday. I don't blame Amazon. I am located in Colombia, South America. It is so slow that some garments never arrive, but produce no error. And dirty errors are higher than yesterday Tuesday ( but discounting the two brief collapses of Tuesday ) There are a few ugly minutes and many minutes of perfection. I love Amazon and I have high trust in the AWS Team and the Programmers. What we need is that Top Management at AMZN gives the necessary Computer Servers, Super Disks, Super Modems and Super Material for a Happy Halloween to Christmas ECS Service. The necessary electronic and programming materials should be apportioned to avod high loads of visitors that drive the ECS System to its knees. And some regard for little bees too \!!! description:
Apparel XSLT Examples and Observations
<FONT face="Times New Roman,Times,Serif"><FONT size="4" /></FONT> 
<FONT face="Times New Roman,Times,Serif"><FONT size="4">Apparel XSLT 4.0 Examples</FONT> </FONT>
<FONT face="Times New Roman,Times,Serif" size="3">And Observations about Performance, Missing Images and Wrong Descriptions.</FONT>
<FONT face="Times New Roman" size="3" /> 
Hi Friends :
Using the Examples that Elena kindly has made public for all of us in this thread :
Scratchpad - code samples auto generated
http://forums.prospero.com/n/mb/message.asp?webtag=am-assocdevxml&msg=6472.1&ctx=0
Then I built my own simplified XSLT sytlesheet and I published it on the same thread of the link that I posted above. It is just my reduced stylesheet version of what Elena posted.
Thinks have worked generally well. I converted many of my Apparel Pages using my reduced stylesheet. Most days the rate of failure of my XML-XSLT calls is very low 1% or 2%, but some days like today Thursday the errors are unusually High 5% to 10% of calls. 
At the same time I have been unable to find a single error in XSLT 3.0 ( for books and DVDs ) during the last three months. And I am an obsessive neurotic and compulsive checker of Datafeeds in my Pages.
Also many images are missing in several brands of Apparel. Some descriptions in Newport News Swimsuits are "very dirty" with tags like <li> and other tags.
I am somewhat ashamed of asking for help here, but I am forced by economic cirncunstances to work as a Consultant outside in Factories and Offices and therefore I lack time to devote to studying these things of XSLT 4.0
My Amazon revenue is not enought to justify FULL TIME.
Has someone examples of XSLT 4.0 for Apparel ??
Can we force the link to Item Datafeed  in Elena's Stylesheet sample to open in a New Window, instead of the same Window ???
And if I am calling the garment from an <iframe> tag, Can I force the link to invade all the window ??? ( Maximized Window ) instead of the datafeed appearing only inside the <iframe> ???
Can we get the availability ??? ..... Can we get the colors and sizes ???  ....  By automatic datafeed ??? 
I apologize again to all Associate and to Amazon if I appear as a parasite bloodsucker. As a sort of Apparel XSLT Dracula sucking the work and effort of others, but I really can not devote time to studying a lot of manuals and documentation. I need examples.
I love Amazon, the Apparel and the Associates. And I plan to stay here. 
Besides I am an incorrigible optimist that thinks that things ( and sales ) are going to improve a lot in the future and that we better be stubborn as mules. I am an innate believer in "EL Dorado" and the "Seven Cities of Gold" and maybe I am right !!
I also think that Amazon is going to improve the servers for Apparel XSLT 4.0 and that they are going to work so perfectly in the future as XSLT 3.0 does now for Books and DVDs, where things never fail and there is no 'throttling' for little Honeybees like me.
Thanks for any help
Vicente

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
BUG: Missing types in the WSDL of AWIS
Type attributes are missing in some element decralations in the WSDL.

When using Java(Apache Axis), this may cause a following exception. 
"org.xml.sax.SAXException: No deserializer for {http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema}anyType"
And we can not get any informations, even if a response from AWIS is valid.

Example of missing types:
 <xs:complexType name="WebSearchType">
 <xs:sequence>
 <xs:element name="SearchPhrase" type="xs:token"/>
*<xs:element name="TotalCount"/>
*<xs:element name="Results">

TopSites/Links/Link/AverageReview
*<xs:element name="AverageReview"/>

What we can do:
It is safe to add type as string.
<xs:element name="ElementName" type="xs:string" />

I could avoid SAXException by this.

takeuma

Thanks

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Simple Command-Line Access to Amazon EC2 and Amazon S3
If "aws" isn't working for you, the first thing to do is to add -vv (that's two "v"s) to the command line.  "aws" will then produce a bunch of output that might give you a hint what's going wrong.Here are some common issues:* system time is wrong - Requests are valid for only 30 seconds (hardwired into "aws" and can be chanced if you must), so if your system clock is wrong, you might get timeouts.* system ssl certificates are wrong - "aws" uses "curl" to do the actual work, and curl will complain if your ssl certificates aren't right.  Either fix your certificates or try --insecure-aws to tell "aws" to tell "curl" to not worry about the authentication step.* some commands seem to be missing - Make sure to download the latest version at http://timkay.com/aws/If "aws" doesn't work for you, please contact me.  I am on Skype, AIM, and Yahoo as "timkay" and on MSN as "timkay@hotmail.com".  Or send email to timkay@not.com.-- Tim

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Re: Simple Command-Line Access to Amazon EC2 and Amazon S3
Added a few new features for the S3 support.  Make sure to download aws-1.12 (which isn't the default version offered).* get and set ACLs (via "?acl")* get and set Location Constraints (via "?location")* automatically set Content-Type (using mime.types file)* get to directory target, so you don't have to repeat the object name ("aws get public681/tim.jpg .")

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
supports Elastic Block Store (ECB)
ECB was announced today, and I added support today.  I haven't updated the documentation yet but will soon.  It works the same as in the Amazon documentation.

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Lots of enhancements recently
I have added lots of enhancements to "aws" recently.  For a quick summary, see http://timkay.com/aws/Changes.txt .  For examples, see http://timkay.com/aws/howto.html .Some of the new features:- sanity checks (that your clock isn't off, that your SSL certs work, etc.)- directory targets, so you can say, for example, "s3cp mybucket/foo ."- support for more than 1,000 objects per bucket and prefixes- ability to iterate over all buckets or all objects in a bucket- lots of tweaks and bug fixes

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Support for EU region (and other changes)
See http://timkay.com/aws/Changes.txtaws-1.22 2008-11-19, 2008-12-17        * use EC2 protocol version 2008-12-01        * add describe-regions        * add --region=eu (or us, eu-west-1, us-east-1)        * added -S to enable better curl error reporting        * for addkey, output just the new key, so it can be redirected into the key file        * for get-console-output, display just the output        * make Time::Local optional (it is missing on some systems), possibly disabling          clock skew sanity checkaws-1.21 2008-10-24, 2008-11-10        * update to protocol version 2008-08-08        * added support for setting Cache-Control (Thanks, Ming!)        * added support for Range: and If-*: (Thanks, Stephen Kwong!)        * --verbose (level 1) now clears $verbose variable        * changed --install to copy to /usr/bin (not symlink) (Thanks, Greg Higgins!)        * changed --secretsfile to --secrets-file        * added --limit-rate=N (eg., 200K, 3m, 1G) (Thanks, Dan Colish!)aws-1.20 2008-10-13, 2008-10-14 (Thanks, Nilesh Patel!)        * added --expire-time=\d+{m,h,d,w,mo,y}        * added --dns-alias indicates to use bucket name as a host name        * added --http to use http rather than https        * quoted space (%20) and hash (%23) - hash is quoted for --requestaws-1.19 2008-10-09        * automatically pretty print xml if no output is generated        * add --secretsfile option to specify path to secret fileaws-1.18 2008-09-22        * added --exec optionaws-1.17 2008-09-15        * swapped order of processing @ARGV and ~/.awsrcaws-1.16 2008-09-09, 2008-09-14, 2008-09-15        * added -l, -t, -r, --simple (e.g., "aws ls -l test681")        * allow - parameters to be combined (e.g., "-ltr")        * applied same ls options to bucket listings (e.g., "aws ls -l")        * fixed sha1_sha1, which was setting $t globally        * disable sanity check warnings when not a tty        * updated documentation        * fixed quoting, so headers work under Windows        * added --insecure-signing to replace --insecureaws-1.15 2008-09-03, 2008-09-05        * added support for more than 1,000 objects (Thanks, Aaron Nall!)        * warn about ~/.awssecret existence and permissions        * warn if SSL certs don't work        * added ls method to support prefix: "aws ls BUCKET PREFIX"        * added --simple ls-style output

description:
Re: Support for EU region (and other changes)
I'm trying to copy all of an existing bucket in the US to Europe.I managed to create the bucket in Europe with aws mkdir but the copy fails probably because I don't understand the syntax.I thought I could do this:aws --v copy target /source/image.*but I get a 404 errorthe verbose output givesaws version: v1.30  (protocol version 2008-12-01)vhost=pkeurope.s3.amazonaws.com  vname=image.*data = PUT


1236888792
x-amz-copy-source:/source/image.*
/target/image.*curl  -q -S --retry 3 -s  --header "Expect: "  --header 'x-amz-copy-source:/source/image.*' --request PUT --dump-header -  --location 'https://target.s3.amazonaws.com/image.*?AWSAccessKeyId=xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx'HTTP/1.1 404 Not FoundWhat have I misunderstood?

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Re: Support for EU region (and other changes)
I am sorry it took me so long to respond....  I don't normally watch these messages.  (I just changed my profile, so I get email when posts show up here.  Yay!)The short answer is that you can't use wildcards with "aws".  You'll have to write a loop that invokes "aws" for each file you want to copy."aws" does have a --exec="..." feature which will do the looping for you.  It would be something like this:aws ls source/image. --exec='system "aws copy target /$bucket/$key"'However, I need to look into copying across regions.  I don't know if it is supported.  If not, you could do something like this:aws ls source/image. --exec='system "aws get $bucket/$key |aws put target/$key"'For quicker response, please contact me at timkay@not.com

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Re: Support for EU region (and other changes) I just checked on support for S3 EU buckets, and "aws" seems to handle them just fine.  First, to create a bucket in EU:
$ aws mkdir eu.timkay.com -        EU$ aws get eu.timkay.com?locationEU
Second, to copy:
$ aws copy eu.timkay.com /s3.timkay.com/tim.jpg307 Temporary Redirect+--------------------------+|       LastModified       |+--------------------------+| 2009-03-17T20:17:51.000Z |+--------------------------+
The "307 Temporary Redirect" message happens with all S3 EU transactions.  I'll see if I can suppress it.The --exec methods I mentioned in the previous messages should work.

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Re: Auto-scaling Amazon EC2 with Amazon SQS
Hi,The following link http://www.rightscale.com/m/products.html#rightgrid no longer exists.  Please use this link instead:  http://www.rightscale.com/products/cloud-computing-uses/grid-computing.phpFor updated RightGrid documentation, please visit this link instead:http://support.rightscale.com/12-Guides/RightGrid_User_Guide-RightScale

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Re: Auto-scaling Amazon EC2 with Amazon SQS
If you struggle with setup of Auto Scaling you can use online service like Elastic Cloud Gate  which offer auto scaling wizard that will walk you through the whole setup.
You will get option to setup scaling based on demand, schedule or exact capacity. 
Also, you will find explanation of all options that can be used in auto scaling

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Re: Auto-scaling Amazon EC2 with Amazon SQS
there are several CloudWatch metrics related to SQS which can guide your auto-scaling decision: ApproximateNumberOfMessagesVisible, NumberOfMessagesSent, etc

check out  Monitoring Amazon SQS with CloudWatch for more details

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Re: Amazon EC2 Command-Line Tools
Hi Niran,The ec2-bundle-vol command is a part of the EC2 AMI command line tools, not the EC2 API tools.  The AMI tools are included in the Amazon-provided AMIs, but if you're running an instance of a community provided AMI, it is possible they might be missing.  In which case, you can download them to your instance from here:http://developer.amazonwebservices.com/connect/entry.jspa?externalID=368&categoryID=88Also, here's the documentation for both the EC2 AMI and API command line tools (in case you're interested in that):http://docs.amazonwebservices.com/AWSEC2/latest/CommandLineReference/Best Regards,-Cindy

description:
Re: Amazon EC2 Command-Line Tools - issues with BAT files
I'm trying to script a simple workflow where I start and instance and then associate an elastic IP with that instance.  I have set up the EC2 command line tools and can successfully accomplish these tasks using the tools if I open a command window and run the tools separately in the CMD window.I now want to put these commands in a BAT file and have them run sequentially (separated by a TIMEOUT command to wait a few minutes between starting the instance and associating the EIP), but have not been successful with this.The issue is that when I launch my BAT file as soon as the first command runs (ec2-start-instances), the CMD window closes and does not run the subsequent commands.The first tool does in fact run (if I check the AWS console my instance is started).  Typically, I can even see the tool feedback (e.g., INSTANCE i-abcd1234 stopped running) flash in the command window an instant before it closes.Here's the contents of my BAT file (with paths, instance names, etc. changed):ec2-start-instances -C C:\....abc123.pem -K C:\....abc123.pem i-abcd1234timeout 180ec2-associate-address -C C:\....abc123.pem -K C:\....abc123.pem 0.0.0.0 -i i-abcd1234PAUSEI have tried this on two separate machines, one Windows 7 and one Windows Server 2008 virtual machine, and have gotten the same exact results.  I am running these tools as a user who is added to the Administrators group (but not the built-in Administrator account).  I also noticed that when I successfully run the commands in the CMD window I open manually the title bar reads "Administrator: c:\Windows\system32\cmd.exe" but when the BAT file opens the CMD window the title bar reads simply "C:\Windows\system32\cmd.exe"I'm passing the paths to the key/certificate rather than using environment variables since I will be managing several Amazon accounts.I am ideally looking not just for a workaround, but hopefully an explanation as to why things are different run from the BAT file.Thanks for any help you can provide!!!

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
A script implementing the Amazon API Signature Version 4 Signing Process
The following script implements the Amazon Query API Signature v4 signing process using standard tools available in many base Linux operating system installations.  It is a handy way of accessing various services if a particular CLI is missing.

AWS_API_CMD.sh
#!/bin/bash
#
# A script implementing the Amazon API Signature Version 4 Signing Process.
#
# See the following URL for more technical details:
# http://docs.aws.amazon.com/general/latest/gr/sigv4-create-canonical-request.html
#
# Examples:
#   ./AWS_API_CMD.sh ap-southeast-1 sns POST / 'Action=CreateTopic&Name=NotifyMe'
#   ./AWS_API_CMD.sh ap-southeast-1 sqs GET  / 'Action=ListQueues'
#
 
if [ $# -ne 5 ]; then
  echo "Usage: $0 [region] [service] [method] [path] [request]"
  exit 1
fi
 
if [ -z "$AWS_ACCESS_KEY" -o -z "$AWS_SECRET_KEY" ]; then
  echo "ERROR: You must set your Amazon credentials (AWS_ACCESS_KEY & AWS_SECRET_KEY)"
  exit 1
fi
 
Region=$1
Service=$2
Method=$3
Path=$4
 
if [ "$Method" = "POST" ]; then
  QueryString=""
  Payload=$5
else
  QueryString="$5"
  Payload=""
fi
 
#
# Let's try and correctly sort the QueryString (strict ASCII order)
#
if [ -n "$QueryString" ]; then
  QueryString=$(
    {
      saveIFS=$IFS; IFS='=&'; parm=($QueryString); IFS=$saveIFS
      for ((i=0; i<${#parm[@]}; i+=2)); do echo ${parm[i]}=${parm[i+1]}; done
    } | LC_COLLATE=C sort -t'=' -k1,1 | awk '{printf $0"&"}' | sed 's,&$,,'
  )
fi
 
#
# Obtain ISO 8601 Date
#
DateShort=$(date -u -d '+5 sec' +'%Y%m%d')
DateLong=$(date -u -d '+5 sec' +'%Y%m%dT%H%M%SZ')
 
#
# Obtain Location Specific Values
#
Host=${Service}.${Region}.amazonaws.com
 
#
# Create Query/Payload
#
ContentType="application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=utf-8"
 
#
# Hash the Payload
#
Payload_Hash=$(echo -n "${Payload}" | openssl dgst -sha256 | sed 's,^(stdin)= ,,')
 
#
# Create a Canonical Request
#
CanonicalRequest="${Method}
${Path}
${QueryString}
content-type:${ContentType}
host:${Host}
x-amz-date:${DateLong}
 
content-type;host;x-amz-date
${Payload_Hash}"
 
#echo "'$CanonicalRequest'"
 
#
# Hash the Canonical Request
#
Request_Hash=$(echo -n "${CanonicalRequest}" | openssl dgst -sha256 | sed 's,^(stdin)= ,,')
 
#
# Create a String to Sign
#
StringToSign="AWS4-HMAC-SHA256
${DateLong}
${DateShort}/${Region}/${Service}/aws4_request
${Request_Hash}"
 
#echo "'${StringToSign}'"
 
#
# Define a Hash-based Message Authentication Code function
#
HMAC() {
  echo -n "$2" | openssl dgst -sha256 -mac HMAC -macopt "$1" | sed 's,^(stdin)= ,,'
}
 
#
# Calculate the AWS Signature Version 4
#
kSecret=${AWS_SECRET_KEY}
kDate=$(HMAC "key:AWS4${kSecret}" "${DateShort}")
kRegion=$(HMAC "hexkey:${kDate}" "${Region}")
kService=$(HMAC "hexkey:${kRegion}" "${Service}")
kSigning=$(HMAC "hexkey:${kService}" "aws4_request")
 
Signature=$(echo -n "$StringToSign" | openssl dgst -sha256 -mac HMAC -macopt "hexkey:$kSigning" | sed 's,^(stdin)= ,,')
 
#
# Issue the request
#
[ -n "$QueryString" ] && QueryString="?${QueryString}"
curl -s \
     -H "Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=utf-8" \
     -H "X-Amz-Date: $DateLong" \
     -H "host: ${Host}" \
     -H "Authorization: AWS4-HMAC-SHA256 Credential=${AWS_ACCESS_KEY}/${DateShort}/${Region}/${Service}/aws4_request, SignedHeaders=content-type;host;x-amz-date, Signature=${Signature}" \
     -X ${Method} \
     -d "$Payload" \
     "https://${Host}${Path}${QueryString}"


Edited by: K P CLARK on Oct 8, 2013 2:56 PM, Now attempts to sort the Query Parameters correctly.

description:
Petboard: Exception running setup
Im attemptin to walk throguh the PetBoard .net sample but when I run the app and click to import the pet data I get an exception:

+Petboard.DLL!Petboard.Util.BucketHelper.CheckForBucket(string itemKey, Amazon.S3.AmazonS3 s3Client):

An exception of type 'Amazon.S3.AmazonS3Exception' occurred in AWSSDK.dll but was not handled in user code.+

If I click view detail I get the message:

{"The unspecified location constraint is incompatible for the region specific endpoint this request was sent to."}

Stepping throguh I can see that the PutBucketRequest returns me a S3PutWithACLRequest object, but when 

PutBucketResponse putBucketResponse = s3Client.PutBucket(putBucketRequest);

is executed I get the above exception.
Any ideas what this is and why its happening?

Thanks

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Re: Petboard: Exception running setup
I have exactly the same problem as described here. I have tried changing the region however the error persists. Did you ever resolve it?

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Re: Petboard: Exception running setup
Found the following solution in another thread:

      The location constraint is a required field for all regions except for us-east-1. The 
      PutBucketRequest has a few ways of specifying this value. The easiest way do do
      that is set UseClientRegion to true which means the SDK will set the location
      constraint to whatever region the S3 client is configured for.

So I tried this by adding the line:

      putBucketRequest.UseClientRegion = true;

just after the creation of the new PutBucketRequest object in BucketHelper.cs. This seems to have fixed the problem.

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Re: libsdb: C API Library for Amazon SimpleDB
Hi Peter,

I am trying to use libsdb on Fedora (17). I managed to compile and install it after adding "-lcrypto" to LIB_LIBRARIES variable in mk/headers.mk. However, the test program as well as any program written as suggested in the README gave a segmentation fault. After some digging, I figured out that the problem might be that the curl_global_init is done (in sdb.c) with CURL_GLOBAL_NONE which does not initialize SSL handling in cURL. I changed that initialization to CURL_GLOBAL_ALL. With libsdb thus built, the test program as well as other programs started working fine.

If this is fine, could you please update the main package on Amazon site?

Thanks,
Prasad

Amazon Web Services: Overview of Security Processes
So, you explain what needs to be done, but not HOW to make our products hosted on s3 secure.   SO, how do we make them secure?

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:

Any word on when the SAS70 certification will be completed?

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Re: Amazon Web Services: Overview of Security Processes
Data stored in Amazon S3, Amazon SimpleDB, or Amazon Elastic Block Store is redundantly stored in 
multiple physical locations as a normal part of those services and at no additional charge.  Data that is 
maintained within running instances on Amazon EC2, or within Amazon S3 and Amazon SimpleDB, is 
all customer data and therefore AWS does not perform backups.

That paragraph contradicts itself! Is S3 backed up or not?!

--johnt

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Re: Amazon Web Services: Overview of Security Processes
Is there any plan to obtain FISMA certification?

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Re: Amazon Web Services: Overview of Security Processes
John,I think that AWS is considering a "backup" as a physically separate, point-in-time copy of the data stored in S3, EBS, etc. For example, if you have an application that writes garbage data to your EBS or S3 you will have 2 perfectly replicated copies of that garbage. But you won't have a "good" backup unless, for example, you made an EBS snapshot to S3 at a specific point-in-time that has not been altered by your applications. AWS is protecting your data from their hardware failures but not from your application issues. You have to "backup" your own data to do that.John

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description: Re: Amazon Web Services: Overview of Security Processes Hi All, I am wondering whether it is possible to have a token based security system. The reason I ask is if you have a Rich Client like AIR/Flex, you don't necessarily want files to be uploaded/downloaded by the user through your mid tier, but directly to S3, or perhaps be able to run a selection of authenticated queries via SimpleDB.As I am not aware of a token based system, the only way to proceed as is, is with a very limited approach of securing buckets, and then providing private access keys to users. This is obviously not the most ideal approach.Without passing data through a mid-tier other than possibly authenticating with a username/password, how would you go about authenticating and providing access to only parts of a bucket, or to provide limited functionality within the bucket? I have blogged about this at http://swarmcomputing.blogspot.com/2010/03/security-in-cloud-avoiding-equivalent.htmlI would love to hear what people have to say about the matter.

description:
Re: Digest::HMAC_SHA1 is required
I was able to resolve this issue. As per the comment above, it says to install Crypt::SSLeay. I installed that and I was still getting the same error. I was getting the error below

Caught Exception: Internal Error
Response Status Code: 501
Error Code: 
Error Type: 
Request ID:

In general I started googling for "perl https request 500 error" and someone suggest to check if openssl and openssl-devel packages are installed. Ran yum and it was not installed

yum install openssl
yum install openssl-devel

Ran the example and still the same error. Tried re-installing the "Crypt::SSLeay" library. While installing it gives the option of running live tests. Earlier I had marked "no" to that but this time marked a "yes" and it showed that some test failed because the package "LWP::Protocol::https" was not available so I installed that and re-ran the SSLeay force install. I still got the error that 1 test failed and that site "rt.cpan.org" was not responding but install was successful. Now I no longer get the internal error and examples work fine. Hope it helps

cpan install LWP::Protocol::https
cpan force install Crypt::SSLeay

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Re: Amazon RDS DB Instance Sizing Guide
I know this is really old, but we did this twice yesterday when moving a 50gb database (larger allocation, but ~50gb data) from a large to an m1.xlarge.

"brief outage" was 20 minutes. Connections were unavailable for about 10 minutes in the middle of that period.

Apparently you do NOT want to take a snapshot immediately after upgrading a multi-AZ database. We confirmed this with another devops person after we made that mistake. (major DB lag since there's no replica for a short while)

description:
Re: Browser Uploads to S3 using HTML POST Forms
I generated the signature with PHP5 this way (assume $policy is filled in, and $secretkey is the secret key):$signature = base64_encode(hash_hmac('sha1', $policy, $secretkey, TRUE));It took a while to figure that out.If you're using PHP4, I found a solution here:http://blog.raamdev.com/2008/05/03/amazon-s3-hmac-signatures-without-pear-or-php5/

description:

Forgot to mention, $policy should be base 64 encoded before signing, like the other examples above.

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Re: Browser Uploads to S3 using HTML POST Forms
To those people who reported problems generating a signature value using the example Java code in this article, can you confirm whether or not the calculated signature worked when you attempt to upload a file?There can be subtle differences between policy documents generated by different code, and these differences will produce entirely different signature values. For example, something as simple as an extra space or newline character will lead to a different signature value, even though the important parts of the policy document are identical.I am interested to know whether the example Java code fails in some cases, or whether it just happens to produce different signature values that still work when you actually submit the form?

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Re: Browser Uploads to S3 using HTML POST Forms
It is only necessary to remove newline characters if your Base64 implementation introduces them when encoding data. Some implementations add newlines to keep text lines short, others don't. Most Base64 decoders can cope with either version, but AWS doesn't like the extra newlines.

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Re: Browser Uploads to S3 using HTML POST Forms
If it is vital for you to encrypt uploaded files before they are stored in S3, you could use a browser applet application such as my own Cockpit Lite. This would require supporting software on both the server- and client-side to emulate the anonymous upload functionality that Amazon's browser uploads already provides, but it is possible and would give you complete control over the upload.PM me if you are interested in discussing this further -- it's a bit off-topic for this forum.

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Re: SignatureDoesNotMatch error while uploading file......
Make sure that your policy document exactly matches the contents of your HTML form fields. If the policy document has different values from the HTML form, or if the policy is missing a field that is defined in the form, the signature generated from the policy will be invalid.Unfortunately it can be hard to work out which values are incorrect because the error message from AWS doesn't give any detail. Look carefully at every field in your HTML form and make sure there is a corresponding field with the appropriate value in the policy document.For example, in ashiv's HTML form the fields "success_action_redirect" and "acl" have different values than those in the policy document.

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Re: How to Implement the Code...
The code examples show how to generate the policy and signature values you need to include in the HTML form. In the POST form template near the beginning of the article there are some capitalised values you need to replace. These values include YOUR_POLICY_DOCUMENT_BASE64_ENCODED and YOUR_CALCULATED_SIGNATURE, which are place holders for the generated policy and signature values respectively.I have attached a very primitive Java class that pulls everything together. If you compile and run this code, it will print out an HTML document that contains an S3 POST form. Once you have edited this code to include your own AWS credentials, policy document and HTML template values, it should generate usable upload forms.Good luck!James

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Re: How to Implement the Code...
You will need to download Sun's Java software development kit to compile and run the Java code. To make the process easier, you may prefer to use a development environment like Eclipse or NetBeans.The Java code uses cryptographic tools to calculate a signature value that is unique to your policy document and AWS credentials, as well as base64-encoding this value. Once the values have been generated, you include them in the HTML document. You do not need to include the Java code that created them.Getting started with Java, Ruby or Python is too big a topic for this forum but you should be able to find many resources on the 'net to help you learn.

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Re: How to Implement the Code...
The URL to access private S3 objects must be generated using a whole other request signing algorithm, you cannot use the same signature value as the one in the HTML POST form.If you need to generate URLs to expose your private objects, look for the S3 documentation about "Signed URLs" for instructions.The easiest thing would be to find an S3 client tool that is able to generate signed URLs. My Cockpit Java applet can do this, as can some other clients. Cockpit is free and is available here: http://jets3t.s3.amazonaws.com/applications/cockpit.html

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:

Hi James,Thanks for prompt reply.We need programming logic to do this. And I am trying to use REST service("org.jets3t.service.impl.rest.httpclient.RestS3Service") api.Is there any reference to use this REST service to generate signed URLs. Also, I am referring the following URL for signed URLs part http://docs.amazonwebservices.com/AmazonS3/2006-03-01/ .  Is this the reference URL to S3 documentation about Signed URLs?Thanks,Sarath.

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Is ec2 the right Option?
We would like to use the cloud much as people typically usea blade farm.  We want to be ableto write a script that automatically launches a large series of independentjobs, which would each run on a separate machine in the cloud. The jobs wouldconsist of the same java program running on different inputs.  Each job would produce an outputfile.  If, in addition, it would bepossible to have another program process all the output files on the cloud, orat least automatically download them for local processing, that would be ideal.


In reviewing the available introductory material on cloudcomputing we have not found anything that seems directly relevant to a simpleimplementation of this paradigm. Do facilities already exist to do what we want, or is the cloud not theappropriate enviroment?

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Re: Amazon S3 POST Example in Flash
I have been unable to get the Flash upload example to work.  I get 403 errors every time.  Here is my policy (except with my actual bucket filled in):
{ 
    'expiration': '2008-09-01T12:00:00.000Z',
    'conditions': [
      	{'bucket': ,'<MY_BUCKET>'},
	{'acl': 'private'},
	{'key': '$filename'},
	['starts-with','$Content-Type', ''],
	['starts-with','$Filename',''],
	['eq','$success_action_status','201'],
     ] 
}

Originally I thought maybe I was having problems using contentType audio/mpeg, so I instituted the allow all content types rule above, but that didn't change anything.  From what I've seen, that policy should work, but I keep getting errors saying, "An IO error occurred: [IOErrorEvent type="ioError" bubbles=false cancelable=false eventPhase=2 text="Amazon S3 returned an error: HTTP status 403."]"  I've uploaded a crossdomain.xml file allowing all access too.  Any ideas?  Thanks!

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Re: Amazon S3 POST Example in Flash
I believe the issue is policy related indeed. I believe that without a policy validator that could serve coders from many languages, i.e. .net, ruby, php, flash a great deal of time is wasted on Amazon support, forums, etc.

Imagine coding without a debugger. We'd still be in the year 1981. Imagine web dev sans firebug. Validation makes everybody happy. The amazon online policy generator was a step in the right direction but it would be great if they had a secure online utility so those poor 403 victims could quickly get to the root of the issue as everytime I get a 403 I hear boss tell me, "What we have here is a fayyylyur to koomyooonicayt!"

Yikes.. and I hate hardboiled eggs. So a validator for policies would be a great policy!

:))

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Re: Amazon S3 POST Example in Flash
Cary S. Abramoff wrote:
I believe the issue is policy related indeed. I believe that without a policy validator that could serve coders from many languages, i.e. .net, ruby, php, flash a great deal of time is wasted on Amazon support, forums, etc.

...

So a validator for policies would be a great policy!

You can use this one to validate your policy and signature are both correct:

http://www.jfileupload.com/products/js3upload/documentation/policygenerator.html

create an AMI off this instance
launch an instance off this new AMI

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Re: Oracle BPM 11gR1 Patchset 2
Make sure you open ports 5901 - 5905 through your security group firewall.

In  the TightVNC client I usually put in external_hostname:port

For example: ec2-xxx-xxx-xxx-xxx.compute-1.amazonaws.com:5901

description:
any plans to support OVF ?
The Open Virtualization Format looks promising and is already supported by VMware and VirtualBox. It would be fantastic if there was a migration tool for compatible (ie: Xen enabled) ovf VMs to ec2 AMI format.
At the very least, could you please issue a statement with your plans regarding OVF in the FAQ?

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Re: any plans to support OVF ?
I am interested in this as well. At certain point, developers might want to export the AMIs in OVF and run them locally.

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Re: any plans to support OVF ?
In addition it would be great to work on a virtual machine locally (using VMWare or an equivalent), get it the way you want it, then export it to the AWS cloud.

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Re: any plans to support OVF ?
I'd be very interested in this from an enterprise point of view.  I work for SAP and many of my customers that are looking to cloud (public, private, external) are all worried that they will get locked in.  This could go a long way towards providing that portability that many considering cloud could use to ensure that there is a standard migration path between the different cloud providers.

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Re: any plans to support OVF ?
To answer this question, one might put oneself in Amazon's position as a thought experiment.
 AWS is a market-segment leader -- retail public cloud computing-- with a proprietary format (AMI).  In retail business, customers are very fickle and panicky. In subscription business, costs of subscriber-acquisition dominate costs of subscriber-retention. Since AWS is doing both, it is very important for AWS to have natural barriers against subscriber defections over the whims-du-jour of retail. AMI is a unique technical solution to a unique AWS business problem. AWS will rely on the larger ecosystem to provide instance-packaging solutions (e.g. BitRock, rPath, JumpBox, consultants & integrators), and let them worry about harmonizing the wider industry bloom of instance-formats. AWS will implement OVF support when it impacts AWS subscriptions, and not a second before that. For now, AWS is focused on retail execution and subscriber acquisition, and have built a formidable market position.

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description: Re: Elegant - but what's happening behind the scenes? Firstly, great article.  I got this up and running quickly with no problems.  But, to follow up on this, simple tomcat applications with no backing database are rare.  I would like to know a few things:1.  Can I deploy to an AMI other than the default Tomcat Cluster?  An AMI that has both Tomcat and mysql for example?2.  Can I use the toolkit to take an existing instance, add additional applications (such as kettle or a vpn utility for example) to it,  bundle it and deploy it to s3?3. You don't elaborate much on EBS view, and there is not much in the help docs.  The best description of EBS is that it is like plugging in an external hard drive and gives you extra storage.  What is not clear to me is how to use it within the toolkit.  Looks like you can create new volumes and create a snapshot, but I am uncertain as to how to add anything to the volumes.  Perhaps I am missing the purpose of EBS?Any help is appreciated.

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Re: Clarification on the architecture of the cluster
pidstertl, I applogize for the delay in responding... my comments are inline:Can you clarify the architecture of this cluster?A. I'll do my best... When you specify a certain number of instances, each instance is like a virtual machine running its own Tomcat independently. Think of a load balancer with multiple application servers, only the application servers are EC2 instances - like virtual machines - instead of physical servers. The Elastic IP is assigned to the "virtual load balancer" if you will... The thing is though, there isn't really a load balancer... load balancing within clusters is abstracted within the software that maintains the clusters that are dynamically created within the EC2 infrastructure. I hope I didn't just confuse you more than you were...I will be continuing to write articles on this architecture, so keep an eye out because in each one I try my best to explain this somewhat different architectural paradigm differently than the last time. It isn't easy to pick up right off the bat, but the more you work with it, the more it starts to make sense. As far as session data goes - in general, sessions do not hold session data across a cluster of servers in most cases regardless. As users hit the URI, EC2 distributes them in a "round-robin" fashion. I'm a bit hesitant to say this because I need to confirm it, but as far as I know, the architecture is such that a single user would never be using resources from more than 1 instance at a time... I don't believe it is that kind of distributed system ("DAC" systems are rare for several reasons, but that is beside the point). With that said, the cluster would never have a need to share session data. However, I will double-check on this to make sure because you bring up an interesting point.-Dan

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Re: Clarification on the architecture of the cluster
Apparently I hit submit too soon...The sentence: "As far as session data goes - in general, sessions do not hold sessiondata across a cluster of servers in most cases regardless." should read: As far as session data, sessions are usually not shared amongst servers within a cluster.Sorry if this caused any confusion.As a sidenote, there are exceptions; such as the Adobe EDGE platform for CDN networks... I believe that runs this sort of distributed architecture in order to pump as many data packets as possible from an array of redundant servers for high-bandwidth video streaming, for example. Like I said though, as far as I know this is not the type of architecture of EC2, but I will double check with the development team to make sure.

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Re: Elegant - but what's happening behind the scenes?
Forloop, thank you for the compliment. I am happy to hear you were able to get running with no problems. It took a lot of trial and error before I was able to get that far so I could right this article, so I'm glad it saved you some time. I will answer your questions to the best of my ability...1.  Can I deploy to an AMI other than the default Tomcat Cluster?  An AMI that has both Tomcat and mysql for example?A. This requires a bit more of a global understanding of AWS to understand. The SimpleDB service is intended to provide the data storage solution. The idea here is separation of tiers in the infrastructure, which has its advantages. Let's use a simple example: A Linux/Apache/PHP AMI could be deployed to a cluster of EC2 instances, which simulates the "application tier" in an enterprise network infrastructure where the business logic is separated from the data layer. Then, you would create a sort of "adapter" type of class, which would negotiate a peristent data connection with SimpleDB while the user is running the code on the EC2 instance they are connected to. 2. Can I use the toolkit to take an existing instance, add additionalapplications (such as kettle or a vpn utility for example) to it, bundle it and deploy it to s3?A. This kind of extensibility has not yet been implemented as far as I know, although I imagine that as AWS continues to grow at such a rapid rate, such things will be possible sooner than later.3. You don't elaborate much on EBS view, and there is not much in the helpdocs.  The best description of EBS is that it is like plugging in anexternal hard drive and gives you extra storage.  What is not clear tome is how to use it within the toolkit.  Looks like you can create newvolumes and create a snapshot, but I am uncertain as to how to addanything to the volumes.  Perhaps I am missing the purpose of EBS?A. You caught me red-handed on this one. You are correct that I seemingly skipped over the EBS view. You are also correct in your assumptions about its purpose, although I had not spent much time trying to make it work. It was my understanding at the time of the writing that the integration of the Elastic Block Storage into the toolkit was undergoing some maintenance and code review to get it fully functional, so I believe it is still safe to say that there is nothing that you are missing....yet. I have a feeling that this will be completed soon and this will be evident most likely by documentation updates that include plenty of information on how to use it, along with some tutorials as well I'm sure.

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Re: Elegant - but what's happening behind the scenes?
Nice toolkit and article.

I am having some questions about the contents of the tomcat server AMI 
and the way the eclipse plugin is communicating with the server and configuring it.

As far as I know, the tomcat is deployed on port 8080.
This is a problem as proxies not always allow outbound traffic on that port.
So I decided to change it to port 80.
Changing the Server properties of the EC2 Tomcat Server 
does not help: I changed <eclipse_server>/server.xml to
<Connector connectionTimeout="20000" port="80" protocol="HTTP/1.1" redirectPort="8443" />
without results.

So it seems the deployment of applications to the Tomcat server need some other ports...

When cloning the instance to a new AMI (bundle) I discovered that the tomcat service is not running at all at the server!? Even JAVA_HOME is not configured. 

Anyone more information on these points?

thanks,
Adel

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Re: Elegant - but what's happening behind the scenes?
Adelg, that's something we'd probably want to go straight to the support team with. I'd hate to give you an answer I wasn't completely sure about. I'll see if I can get hold of someone over there and get an answer for you. Thanks,Dan

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Re: Elegant - but what's happening behind the scenes?
Adelg, I take that back, I do have an answer for you. Install the Firefox "ElasticFox" plug-in, select "Security Groups", right click on the default group under "Your Groups", select "Grant New Permission", and add TCP/IP port 80 for HTTP access. VOILA!

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Re: Elegant - but what's happening behind the scenes?
Correction on the last statement, you do not need ElasticFox to open port 80. Simply navigate to "Security Groups" in the EC2 management console, select the respective group and use the bottom panel to open port 80 for http access. ElasticFox is definitely a handy tool though.

description:
Watch out for Tomcat 6.0.24
This tutorial is great BUT for a couple of potential issues...as of July 3, 2010 and using the 1.0.5 version of the AWS SDK/Plug-in for Eclipse, Tomcat 6.0.24 is problematic.  I found the answer in the forums: http://developer.amazonwebservices.com/connect/message.jspa?messageID=169343#169343andhttp://developer.amazonwebservices.com/connect/thread.jspa?threadID=42199&tstart=0Plus, I also removed the Elastic IP as suggested herehttp://developer.amazonwebservices.com/connect/message.jspa?messageID=147053Now Publish, Republish, Run-As, etc all work without errors, using either the Eclipse browser or something like Firefox. I can now SSH to the instance and ps -ef | grep tomcat and see that it is running.

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Re: Amazon Associates Web Service Simple Store in PHP
though example was not maintained code standard, you can overcome those notice by initializing those variables just after the start php tag like below,            $CartId = empty($_GET['CartId']) ? '' : $_GET['CartId'];            $HMAC = empty($_GET['HMAC']) ? '' : urlencode($_GET['HMAC']);hope above will reduce notices

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Re: Amazon Associates Web Service Simple Store in PHP There is one little thing missing in this script. The showCartContents function does not check for an empty cart so you get this warning on an empty cart: Warning: Invalid argument supplied for foreach() in xxxxxx\SimpleStore.php on line 231The solution is to wrap test code aroun the foreach() statement as below: I purposely did not format correctly so that is sticks out.if (isset($parsed_xml->Cart->CartItems)){    foreach($parsed_xml->Cart->CartItems->CartItem as $current){        $CartItemId = $current->CartItemId;        $remove="SimpleStore.php?Action=Remove&CartId=$CartId&HMAC=$HMAC&CartItemId=$CartItemId";        print("".$current->Title.": ".$current->Price->FormattedPrice."   (Remove from Cart)");    }    print("Subtotal: ".$parsed_xml->Cart->CartItems->SubTotal->FormattedPrice."");} else {    print("Your Cart is empty");}Also, contrary to the documentation, you can do a cartAdd even if the item is already in the cart but this script does not show the quantity in the showCartContents function.The fix is to change the print statement to: print("".$current->Title.": ".$current->Price->FormattedPrice."
QTY: ".$current->Quantity."   (Remove from Cart)");A great  learning tool. Message was edited by: Robert Bonomo

description:
Re: Amazon Associates Web Service Simple Store in PHP
I am guessing because of the release date this product is not compliant with the new API?

Anyone know any full stores that are open source that are compliant with the August cutoff date?

I use MrRats Amazon store like many out there but it seems development has ended for that project and the new Product Advertising API will not be supported.

I am also looking through a number of Store Scripts and seeing that even the pay ones are outdated and no new info is available.

Seems that people have either lost interest in supporting Amazon Stores or they have given up software development as a whole due to economic conditions.

It would be reasonable for Amazon to not just provide a sample script but something usable that can be templated considering all the factors out there.

If someone could point me in the right direction of a free script 

I have been searching for about a week now with nothing found 
Thanks

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Re: Amazon Associates Web Service Simple Store in PHP
I have recently upgraded my PHP script on:http://www.chipdir.nl/amazon/so it will keep working after august 15.The script still isn't perfect yet, but it works and has a lotof useful comments in the source code (as someoneremarked via email). It has a flag with which you canenable or disable the new mechanism which isn't veryuseful after august the 15'th of course and I will removethe old code parts later. Until that date you can stilltest both variations of the script which might helpdebug your situation.Feel free to email me with questions or suggestionsor whatever to encourage me to spend more time onthe script. I can understand that my old friend Mr. Rat has stoppeddeveloping his script because Amazon keeps changingthe rules of the game.Anyway, my script works as it is, except that you have toinclude your own two Amazon keys from august 15'thonwards.Someone noted that my script works perfectly under Linux etc.but provokes a lot of 'notices' under Windows, but my scripts are usuallyvery solid so just disable these warnings by using the error_reporting function:error_reporting(error_reporting()&~E_NOTICE);I'll add this to the script the next time I'll edit it.To Amazon: I think that you should refer to my script and refer to it as seemingly the leading (because only) independent PHP script that has survived all of Amazon's noncompatible programming interface changes.Most other scriptwriters have given up by now...

description:
Re: Amazon Associates Web Service Simple Store in PHP
Hi Glenys,If you are an Amazon Associate with a question regarding getting paid, please use the Amazon Associates contact form:https://affiliate-program.amazon.com/gp/associates/contactIf you have a technical question about the Amazon Product Advertising API, then please post in their developer forum located here:http://developer.amazonwebservices.com/connect/forum.jspa?forumID=9&start=0If you are not using the Amazon Product Advertising API, but would like to discuss the Amazon Associates program with other associates, then please post to the Amazon Associates discussion boards, which are found here:https://affiliate-program.amazon.com/gp/associates/login/login.htmlBest Regards,-Cindy

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
How can I track which specific visitors to my site completed a purchase?
I plan on using various marketing vehicles to bring people to my site.  Each vehicle will create a unique session ID that encodes the marketing vehicle ID and date.  I'm not sure which vehicle will draw the most buyers (purchases) vs. the most lookers (abandoned carts), so I would like to be able to associate each purchase with the associated session ID.  When a purchaser has decided to purchase and I get a PURCHASE-URL, I can track if the user clicks on the PURCHASE-URL, but how do I know for sure that the purchase went through?  Is there a confirmation process?  Or can I pass my session ID to Amazon and have purchases tied to both my Associate ID an my own proprietary session ID in some sort of report?Thanks,Don Leatham

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Re: How can I track which specific visitors to my site completed a purchase?
if you are tracking a few vehicles that bring users to your site you could categorize them into different associate Ids. this is a bit of hassle but it would get you the info you want.When it comes to individual users I'm not sure. that would be interesting and I think that as a user I'd mind if a refering website was able to track that I bought something trough their link.

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Are there any working public OpenSuSE AMI's that used these instructions?
I've tried to follow the instructions in this guide with a SuseStudio built OpenSuSE 11.3 image (x86_64 version).  I've used the kernel-ec2 package instead of the kernel-default, and SuseStudio (kiwi) produced a single ext3 partition'd disk (i.e. /dev/sda1 = /).  I then mounted the ext3 partition inside and tweaked the /boot/grub/menu.lst and /etc/fstab files according to the instructions in this guide.I uploaded the disk image into a EBS volume and registered it to use the PVGrub boot-kernel for EBS+x86_64 (aki-4e7d9527).  So when I start instances based on the generated AMI, the console output seems to indicate it found the grub's menu.lst fine.  However, the instance doesn't seem to do a proper mounting of the / filesystem and is later unable to find /etc/inittab to get the init level which causes the kernel to crash.If there was an example AMI out there I could look at, then I could try to emulate its settings, but everything that I can find so far is based off a different distro like Fedora.

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Re: Are there any working public OpenSuSE AMI's that used these instructions?
The guide has one thing that is misleading.  You really want the hd0 not the hd00 PV GRUB, even if you are using EBS.  If it still doesn't work, let me know.

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Re: Are there any working public OpenSuSE AMI's that used these instructions?
I just tried that, and it didn't even get as far as the PVGrub didn't find the menu.lst file (hung at domgrub> prompt) since my generated disk is partitioned.  According to another page, the 'hd0 PVGrub should only be used with disks that are not partitioned but just a single filesystem without an MBR:http://www.ioncannon.net/system-administration/1205/installing-cent-os-5-5-on-ec2-with-the-cent-os-5-5-kernel/

"VGRUB understands standard grub.conf or menu.lst commands"If I'm trying to work with a distribution that uses grub.cfg should I create a menu.lst as well (in addition to grub.cfg), should I make a symbolic (or hard?) link from grub.cfg to menu.lst, should I rename grub.cfg to menu.lst, ...? Please advise.Cheers!

I'm installing my own license for SQL Server 2008 on the Basic Microsoft Windows Server 2003 (AMI Id: ami-de4daab7).

When I initially install everything is fine. I install everything on the C drive. I use the local Administrator account and created my own account.

I then bundle this into a new bundle and register it as one of my own. 

I then terminate the original instance. 

When I launch a new instance with my new bundled AMI I am not able to connect to the SQL Server Database Engine. 

I am able to connect to the Analysis Services without an issue.

I believe the issue with with the hostname / computer name. After I bundle and relaunch the hostname changes. I believe this is causing a problem when SQL Server is looking for windows authentication. 

Has anyone else run into this or a similar problem? Suggestions on how to fix it?

description:
File upload corrupted
I'm uploaded a 768K video file using the Perl s3RestTool from links from Amazon.  (Did it twice to make sure!)After downloading via straight HTTP neither played correctly so I did a binary compare and sure enough it failed.Is there a special setting I need to set with this tool or Amazon or is it just perhaps a bug of the tool?PeteThanks in advance!

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Re: File upload corrupted
I've uploaded and downloaded, checking for integrity, some pretty big files with this tool like so:



s3RestTool.pl -i my_id -s my_secret_key -m PUT -b mybucket -f ./foo.avi -k /foo.avi -p -c video/x-msvideo


-p is to set the public acl
-c is the mime type
-f is the local file
-k is the bucket key
-b is the bucket

description:

"aws_access_key_id) does not pass the type constraint" ... is likely related to the status of your $HOME/.aws  file.   Possibly it is missing, malformed, or your HOME is misdirected.

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Use of XFS for EBS volumes as recomended by article
This is just a heads up to newcomers that there are currently unresolved issues with running xfs file systems on ebs volumes. The causes seem to be unknown and not all distribution/kernel combinations trigger the issues, but if you are getting started with this it might be worth considering the implications and either carefully testing your specific configuration or if your requrements don't mandate it, using another file system.Here are some referencs, and be sure and stay tuned for when Amazon resolves these as I am sure they will soon.http://developer.amazonwebservices.com/connect/thread.jspa?threadID=24584http://developer.amazonwebservices.com/connect/thread.jspa?threadID=24402http://developer.amazonwebservices.com/connect/thread.jspa?threadID=24141http://developer.amazonwebservices.com/connect/thread.jspa?threadID=24314

description:

Eric - thanks for your reply.  Doesn't work, meaning I probably shot myself in the foot somehow .  After saving an AMI with the fstab changes you recommended, I created a new instance using the new AMI, detached the volume from the original source instance, and attached it to the new instance to test things out.  Two things I've noticed so far:1) In the new AMI, the /etc/mysql, /var/lib/mysql and /var/log/mysql directories are no longer there, but they do exist in /vol.  This disallowed mysql startup.  Not sure how I managed that - I'm still scratching my head.  During the AMI bundling process, I do admit to learning that you can't bundle to an XFS volume :-|, and so during that bumpy learning process things may have gotten fu-bard.2) In the new instance, fstab still has entries for the mysql mappings, plus the /dev/sdh /vol xfs noatime 0 0 entry.  But I still have to mount /vol (I assume because I attach the vol to the new instance post-boot), and the mysql mounts don't work of course, because they don't exist on the instance.   For new instances using just my.cnf to redirect the datadir (etc) I'll still need to mount /vol but I'm hoping to avoid any filesystem weirdness. I'm on your Debian AMI, so not using AppArmor. Feedback appreciated.

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Re: Use of XFS for EBS volumes as recomended by article
jpmalek: If you excluded the directories in the AMI, then you will need to make them again on the new instance.  A simple "mkdir" should work.  Then you can mount the directories from /vol over top of them as described in the tutorial.I'm not sure what you have in your setup, but you might be able to get away with:  sudo mkdir -p /etc/mysql /var/lib/mysql /var/log/mysql  sudo mount -a

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Re: Use of XFS for EBS volumes as recomended by article
Eric - ah, makes sense.  I didn't do any explicit exclusion of the fstab dirs during the bundling process, but it makes sense that bundle-vol might exclude them (?).  Didn't think of that.  You're right about the mkdir and mount commands - that fixed things.  Now that I think about it more, it makes sense to not have those directories in place when instantiating a new instance, so that there's an explicit mount process to go through before mysql will function properly, mysql can't inadvertently use ephemeral storage, and the EBS volume has to get used for datastore.  Nice.

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Re: Use of XFS for EBS volumes as recomended by article
Eric,I just came across your tutorial, and I had the same problem as jpmalek.  The bundling process excludes the /etc/mysql, var/lib/mysql and /var/log/mysql directories.  From a little reading I saw that these directories may need to be added to fstab in order to not be excluded?  Is that the case?  If not, how do you you include these directories in the bundling process so that mysql will start when the bundled instance starts?

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Re: Use of XFS for EBS volumes as recomended by article
swilcher25:The tutorial does not have a bundling process.  I describe (and recommend) starting a new instance using the base public AMI and installing MySQL from scratch before mounting the EBS volume with the database snapshot.if you are rebundling the instance and running that as a new AMI then:1. You don't want the database directories to be in the bundled image.  That's what the EBS volume is for (persistence).2. You don't want MySQL to run when the instance starts because the database is on an EBS volume which is not yet attached or mounted.  On startup of a rebundled image you would need to take steps like:a. Create the empty mysql directories to be mount pointsb. Attach and mount the EBS volumec. Mount the volume's mysql directories in the right placesd. Start MySQLIf you can avoid rebundling an instance and instead automate startup from a base image, things work out better in the long term.

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Re: Ubuntu 10.04 LTS (Lucid Lynx) Server 32-bit
The reboot or stop/start issue on micro images is to do with the ephemeral0 store not being supported on micro.You have to edit the /etc/fstab and remove the /dev/sdb mount. This is when it fails as it cannot mount it.After that it will reboot stop/start. But of course you'll want to use the AWS Console to "Build Image" into your own snapshot so that your changes will persist.

description:
Re: Amazon CloudFront Signed URLs helper tool
Not sure if it's much use to anyone, but I've ported the script to Python so I can more easily make cloudfront signed URLs from Django.

The code is up on githut:

http://github.com/mdales/cfsign.py

I've tried as much as possible to make it a straight port, but it has one tweak which is that you can import it as a module in python and call the encode method to generate a signed URL - so it works both as a command line tool and as a module ready to use for signing. 

All the best

-- Michael

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Re: Amazon S3 Library for REST in Python
metadata was not working in Python 2.5.Replace the GetResponse class with this one, and it works:class GetResponse(Response):    def __init__(self, http_response):        Response.__init__(self, http_response)        metadata = dict(http_response.getheaders())        self.object = S3Object(self.body, metadata)

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Re: Amazon S3 Library for REST in Python
Also, if you wish to retrieve the metadata for an object without retrieving the object itself, add this function to the AWSAuthConnection and/or QueryStringAuthGenerator class:    def get_info(self, bucket, key, headers={}):        return GetResponse(self._make_request('HEAD', bucket, key, {}, headers))The only difference is the 'HEAD' request type, which will not grab the object data.

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Re: Amazon S3 Library for REST in Python
Is there interest in streaming / chunked data handling for large files? I have files that are several GiB and the current approach of reading the entire thing into memory is less than ideal ( Response:__init__: self.body = http_response.read() ). I was going to hack it up with a callback, something like:

data = []
While True:
    chunk = http_response.read(CHUNKSIZE)
    if not chunk:
        break
    if callback:
        callback(chunk)
    data.append(chunk)
self.body = data.join

That way the interface can remain pretty much intact; you'd just pass the callback function into get.

It'd be even nicer if a generator was used to get the body, something like:

While True:
    chunk = http_response.read(CHUNKSIZE)
    if not chunk:
        break
    yield chunk

Any interest in this or am I the only one dealing with large files?

description:
Re: Amazon S3 Library for REST in Python ++ ACL policy parsing and creation
I updated the s3.py file to account for the changes in python 2.6.  I also noticed that there was no object parsing support for ACL lists nor was there any way to create an ACL using an object approach.I added a few additional classes and xml.sax handlers to parse the ACL lists.  There are also some classes for creating ACL policies from scratch.I also embedded the unit tests in the file for compactness but, of course, they don't need to be there for production use.Download the file here:https://plaidcloud.s3.amazonaws.com/public/s3/s3.py.zip

label: Sample Code & Libraries Articles & Tutorials and Amazon Machine Images
description:
Re: Amazon S3 Library for REST in Python ++ ACL policy parsing and creation
After careful consideration, I recommend all users use boto instead for a python s3 library as this library is no longer actively maintained:

http://boto.s3.amazonaws.com/index.html
http://code.google.com/p/boto/

It's not immediately obvious to a new Python user what to do when starting with S3 and Amazon Web Services, but boto is far and away the superior library.
